Award.AwardTitle: EFRI-ODISSEI: Uniting Principles of Folding and Compliant Mechanisms to Create Engineering Systems with Unprecedented Performance
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI) Origami Design for the Integration of Self-assembling Systems for Engineering Innovation (ODISSEI) award is to unite principles of origami and compliant mechanisms to enable the creation of engineered systems with unprecedented performance. Compliant mechanism principles will provide a means to translate origami-based discoveries into engineered systems that achieve desired behaviors. The objective will be accomplished using the following approach: 1) overcome obstacles limiting origami principles from being widely applied to non-paper materials, 2) create design methods that unite origami and compliant mechanism principles, 3) employ the united principles to create engineered systems with unprecedented performance, and 4) exhibit the relationship of origami art to engineering advances. Deliverables include a library of surrogate folds that mimic origami creases, design methods and mathematical modeling approaches for creating origami-based compliant mechanisms, engineered systems that further national goals, student education, broadening participation results, and a traveling museum exhibit with accompanying outreach activities.

Research success will enable advances in applications such as highly compact mechanisms (e.g., medical implants, electronics equipment, and aerospace components), collapsible devices that are compact during transport and deployed at the location of operation (e.g., surgical devices, space mechanisms, and search and rescue systems), and applications with limited manufacturing processes available (e.g., microelectromechanical systems and cost-sensitive applications). Commercialization of the research will demonstrate its potential for real and significant economic impact. Engineering, mathematics, and industrial design students will be intimately involved in all aspects of the research. An exhibit of origami art and its extension to engineering and mathematics will be developed for display nationally.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this award was to unite principles of origami and compliant mechanisms to enable the creation of engineered systems with unprecedented performance. The research plan progressed from more straightforward to higher-risk research tasks. This provided an opportunity for research impact to begin early and extend far into the future and over a broad spectrum of applications.

Key research contributions have made it possible to overcome obstacles and enable origami principles to be widely applied to non-paper materials. This includes the development of surrogate folds, which replace creases in paper with features that mimic the function of creases but are feasible in engineering materials. Approaches for accommodating thickness, concepts related to rigid foldability, and mathematical models for analysis have also been developed.

The research created design methods that unite origami and compliant mechanism principles. Mathematical models that describe the motion and energy behavior of these systems have been instrumental in making it possible to understand, model, and design origami-based engineering systems.  Terminology and design methods have been developed to make it possible for engineers to design new deployable devices that were not possible before.

These principles were employed to create engineered systems with unprecedented performance. Demonstrating the research results in applications helps focus research tasks on those that that provide both fundamental understanding and have potential for impact. A few examples of successful application demonstrators include deployable solar arrays for space applications, deployable ballistic barriers, medical devices for minimally invasive surgery, and consumer products such as a deployable cook stove and tessellation-inspired back packs. Photos of these examples are attached.

The research has reached beyond the university and industry to broader society by exhibiting the relationship of origami art to engineering advances. An exhibit of origami-based engineering has been displayed in three exhibitions in the U.S. and abroad. Videos have reached millions of online viewers, and work with traditional media has stretched to reach a wide segment of society.

Broader impacts include advances in applications  (such as in highly compact mechanisms, collapsible devices that are compact during transport and deployed at the location of operation, and applications with limited manufacturing processes available), education (graduate and undergraduate students have been intimately involved in all aspects of the research), and outreach to wide segments of society (museum exhibitions, online videos, media, a smart phone app, among others).
